Pier Paolo Pasolini's mysterious death continues to haunt Italy, 50 years on
description: The murder of the Italian writer and filmmaker on November 2, 1975, still raises many questions. Among those who have not given up on the case, lawyer Stefano Maccioni fought for years to have judicial proceedings reopened. Now, he places his hopes in the parliamentary inquiry committee that has just been created.

US envoy to Syria announces that Israel and Syria have agreed to a ceasefire
description: The announcement on Saturday came as clashes continued between Druze groups and members of Bedouin clans in Syria’s southern Sweida province. Israel, which bombed the Syrian military in Sweida and Damascus earlier this week to put pressure on the government to withdraw, said Friday that it was sending aid to Sweida's Druze community.

headline: Secondhand medals reveal the existence of Russian intelligence cyber units
description: A new report has analyzed public images of medals from the 16th Center of the Federal Security Service (FSB), Russia's internal intelligence branch responsible for communications espionage, uncovering valuable information about its organization.

headline: Justin Bieber returns with 'Swag,' a polished and confident seventh album
description: After a four-year hiatus and the cancellation of a 2022 tour, the 31-year-old Canadian singer has returned with a new album steeped in R&B sounds.

headline: A day off or not? Making sense of France's public holidays
description: With 11 public holidays each year, France falls slightly below the European average. Prime Minister François Bayrou has proposed scrapping two of them, arguing this would save €4.2 billion annually.

In Syria, a cycle of revenge engulfs the Druze city of Sweida
description: Attacks against Druze civilians, allegedly carried out by members of government forces, have multiplied in recent days in the city of Sweida and its surrounding areas, which remain cut off from the outside world. These attacks have triggered retaliatory violence against Bedouins.

headline: In 1945, 'Elle' instantly set a new standard for French women's magazines
description: 'The Summer of 1945' (4/6). Hélène Gordon-Lazareff, who spent much of World War Two in the United States, returned to France with fresh ideas for the press. She promised her readers 'seriousness in frivolity, irony in gravity.'

headline: In Morocco, score-settling follows a former spy chief's escape abroad
description: Police officers close to Mehdi Hijaouy, a former senior Moroccan foreign intelligence official who was forced into exile after a conflict with his superiors, have been sentenced and his family has been targeted by administrative harassment.
